Expectation1: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation1: A minor signal delay up ahead requires careful speed adjustments to maintain the schedule without causing abrupt movements.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: I sit in the operator’s seat, eyes fixed on the glowing signals ahead. The radio crackles—there’s a minor delay at the next station. I know what’s expected: keep the train safe, adjust my speed, avoid sudden stops. The passengers trust me to get them home on time, and I feel the weight of their silent expectations with every turn of the track. But my mind drifts to the Quran resting in my bag. Tonight, the community study circle gathers, and I’m supposed to have read and reflected on the verses we’ll discuss. I haven’t had the time. My shift ends just before the meeting, and I’d planned to read during my break, but the delay ate up those precious minutes. I feel torn—my duty to these passengers is clear, but so is my commitment to my faith and my community. The train hums forward, and I wrestle with the guilt of not being fully prepared for either role, wondering how I can meet the demands of both when they pull me in opposite directions.
